content.text: Three coplanar forces of magnitudes 40N, 30N and \(X \mathrm{N}\) act at a point in the directions shown in the diagram.
Given that the forces are in equilibrium, find the values of \(\theta\) and \(X\).

A cyclist is travelling along a straight horizontal road at a speed of \(4\mathrm{ms}^{-1}\) when she passes a point \(O\). She accelerates at a constant rate for a distance of \(42\mathrm{m}\), reaching a speed of \(V\mathrm{ms}^{-1}\). She maintains the speed of \(V\mathrm{ms}^{-1}\) for \(50\mathrm{m}\) and then decelerates at \(2\mathrm{ms}^{-2}\) before coming to rest. The distance travelled while decelerating is \(16\mathrm{m}\).
Find the value of \(V\).
Find the total time for which she is in motion from the instant that she passes \(O\).
An aeroplane is flying at a constant speed.

The aeroplane is flying horizontally. The aeroplane's engines are producing a constant power of \(5500\mathrm{kW}\), and the aeroplane experiences a constant horizontal resistance force of \(25\mathrm{kN}\).
Find the speed of the aeroplane.

The aeroplane then ascends \(300\mathrm{m}\) in \(50\mathrm{s}\), while maintaining the same speed. The resistance force is no longer constant, and the work done against the resistance force in ascending the \(300\mathrm{m}\) is \(270000\mathrm{kJ}\). The mass of the aeroplane is \(60000\mathrm{kg}\).
Find the average power of the aeroplane's engines.

Two particles \(A\) and \(B\) have masses \(0.3\mathrm{kg}\) and \(0.1\mathrm{kg}\) respectively. The particles are attached to the ends of a light inextensible string. The string passes over a fixed smooth pulley, and the particles hang vertically below the pulley. Both particles are initially at a height of \(x\mathrm{m}\) above horizontal ground (see diagram). The system is released from rest.
Find the tension in the string and the acceleration of the particles.
During the subsequent motion, \(B\) does not reach the pulley. When \(A\) reaches the ground, it comes to rest.
Given that the greatest height of \(B\) above the ground is \(1.2\mathrm{m}\), find the value of \(x\).

Three particles \(P\), \(Q\) and \(R\), of masses \(0.6\mathrm{kg}\), \(0.4\mathrm{kg}\) and \(0.8\mathrm{kg}\) respectively, are at rest in a straight line on a smooth horizontal plane. The distance from \(P\) to \(Q\) is \(3\mathrm{m}\), and the distance from \(Q\) to \(R\) is also \(3\mathrm{m}\) (see diagram). \(P\) is projected directly towards \(Q\) with speed \(3\mathrm{ms}^{-1}\). After \(P\) and \(Q\) collide, \(P\) continues to move in the same direction with speed \(1.5\mathrm{ms}^{-1}\).
Find the speed of \(Q\) after the collision.
In the subsequent collision between \(Q\) and \(R\), these particles coalesce.
Find the speed of the combined particle after this collision.
Find the time that it takes from when \(P\) is initially projected until the instant at which \(P\) collides with the combined particle.

A block of mass \(12\mathrm{kg}\) is placed on a rough plane inclined at an angle of \(\alpha\) to the horizontal, where \(\alpha = \tan^{-1} 0.5\). A force of \(X \mathrm{N}\) is applied to the block, directly up the plane (see diagram). The coefficient of friction between the block and the plane is \(\mu\).
It is given that \(\mu = 0.15\) and \(X = 20\).
Find the time that it takes for the block to move \(2\mathrm{m}\) down the plane from rest.
It is given instead that \(\mu \neq 0.15\) and that when \(X = 10\), the block is on the point of moving down the plane.
Find the value of \(\mu\) and the value of \(X\) for which the block is on the point of moving up the plane.

A particle moves in a straight line. The velocity \(\nu \mathrm{ms}^{-1}\) of the particle \(t\mathrm{s}\) after leaving a fixed point \(O\) is given by \(\nu = k(20 + pt - 6t^2)\), where \(k\) and \(p\) are constants. The acceleration of the particle at \(t = 1\) is \(42\mathrm{ms}^{-2}\), and the displacement of the particle from \(O\) at \(t = 1\) is \(93\mathrm{m}\).
Show that \(k = 3\) and \(p = 26\).
Find the distance moved by the particle between the time at which its acceleration is zero and the time at which its velocity is zero.
